body_html:
@soumith – That’s a good question. Let me provide some context. I am trying to deploy a model either using PyTorch’s C++ runtime or through the ONNX route. For either case tracing is involved (ONNX export also runs a trace), so I tried running a trace on my model and saw this issue.

The model is for language modeling with shared parameters for word embeddings and output fc layers. I will revisit my model to see opportunities for module reuse, but I feel weight-sharing may be needed. It also helps in terms of reduced model size.

In terms of the larger goal, I can try to use TorchScript annotation instead of tracing to get a script module. Will that be better in this case?

Thanks.

In terms of the larger goal, I can try to use TorchScript annotation instead of tracing to get a script module. Will that be better in this case?

body:
@soumith – That’s a good question. Let me provide some context. I am trying to deploy a model either using PyTorch’s C++ runtime or through the ONNX route. For either case tracing is involved (ONNX export also runs a trace), so I tried running a trace on my model and saw this issue.

The model is for language modeling with shared parameters for word embeddings and output fc layers. I will revisit my model to see opportunities for module reuse, but I feel weight-sharing may be needed. It also helps in terms of reduced model size. 

In terms of the larger goal, I can try to use TorchScript annotation instead of tracing to get a script module. Will that be better in this case?  

Thanks.
